item.title: Dentro de la debacle que llevó al cierre del espacio aéreo de El Paso
item.description: La FAA citó “un grave riesgo de víctimas mortales” por una nueva tecnología usada en la frontera mexicana y se vio atrapada en una discrepancia con el Pentágono, que consideró el arma “necesaria”.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian, Kate Kelly, Eric Schmitt and Tyler Pager
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:description: Steve Feinberg, en el centro, subsecretario de Defensa, durante una reunión en el Pentágono en julio.

item.title: The War in Ukraine Has Become a Way of Life
item.description: The war in Ukraine can look like the future and the past at once. But it’s just our present, the only one we know.
item.dc:creator: Nataliya Gumenyuk

item.title: There’s a Reason American Kids Are Such Picky Eaters
item.description: Blame junk food.
item.dc:creator: Helen Zoe Veit

item.title: Making the Dancing Lions for Lunar New York Celebrations
item.description: In a San Francisco garage, Corey Chan and his team create giant, spectacular lions that will lead the festivities.
item.dc:creator: Miya Lee and Jake Michaels

item.title: Quote of the Day: Love Without Limits: Brazil’s Flirtation With Polyamory
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, February 15, 2026.

item.title: Deep in China’s Mountains, a Nuclear Revival Takes Shape
item.description: Satellite imagery of secretive nuclear facilities reveals Beijing’s efforts to expand its arsenal, just as the last global guardrails on nuclear weapons vanish.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Agnes Chang

item.title: How $40-a-Pack Cigarettes Pushed Australians to the Black Market
item.description: Tax hikes made cigarettes in Australia the most expensive in the world. They have also helped fuel a multibillion-dollar criminal enterprise in bootleg tobacco.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim

media:content.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times

item.title: Will A.I. Kill Translation Jobs?
item.description: Popular paperbacks are being translated with the help of machines, raising anxiety among professionals in the field.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek

media:content.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Browsing a bookstore in Paris. Book publishing is an example of how artificial intelligence is sweeping the translation field.

item.title: Alfred Blumstein, Who Transformed the Study of Crime, Dies at 95
item.description: An engineer by training, he used systems theory and quantitative analysis to examine criminal behavior, revealing the systemic patterns of crime.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Rosenwald

item.title: U.S. Deports Nine Migrants in Secret, Ignoring Legal Protections
item.description: Most had court orders protecting them from removal to their home countries, so they were sent to detention in Cameroon.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar and Hamed Aleaziz

media:content.media:description: An undated photo of the compound where the deportees are being held in Yaoundé, Cameroon’s capital.

item.title: French Prosecutors to Investigate Diplomat as Part of Epstein Probe
item.description: The Paris prosecutor’s office said it was looking into three new complaints with links to the files and revisiting an earlier investigation into an Epstein associate who died in 2022.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic

media:content.media:description: The Santé prison in Paris where Jean-Luc Brunel, a French modeling agent and Epstein associate who died in February 2022, was held.

item.title: Thousands Gather Around the World to Protest Iran’s Government
item.description: Thousands of protesters in several cities across the world took to the streets to demand regime change in Iran on Saturday. The demonstrations came after security forces in Iran violently crushed antigovernment protests in the country, killing thousands of people.
item.dc:creator: Cynthia Silva

media:content.media:description: Protesters held up flags of Iran from before the revolution at a Saturday demonstration organized on the sidelines of the Munich Security Conference.

item.title: Good to the Last Drop
item.description: Michael Lieberman and Rebecca Goldstein’s puzzle looks beyond the horizon.
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Lovinger

media:content.media:description: Look out below.

item.title: No miracle, but Denmark gives U.S. a fight.
item.description: The Americans trailed Denmark after one period, but fought back to cruise to a 6-3 victory.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather and Doug Mills

item.title: Navalny Killed By Frog Toxin, European Governments Say
item.description: Aleksei Navalny was most likely poisoned by a toxin found in a South American frog, five European countries said on Saturday, making the most concrete Western accusation yet that Russia’s leading opposition figure was murdered by his government in 2024.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Mitssunaga

media:content.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Aleksei A. Navalny in his office in Moscow in 2014. He was President Vladimir V. Putin’s most prominent political opponent when he died in a Russian prison in 2024.

item.title: Ring Ends Deal to Link Neighborhood Cameras After Backlash to Super Bowl Ad
item.description: A commercial about a lost dog being reunited with his family ignited concerns that a “Search Party” feature posed privacy risks. Ring parted ways with the tech company Flock Safety.
item.dc:creator: Mark Walker

media:content.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A Ring doorbell security camera on the front of a building in New York. The planned integration of those cameras to activate a search function gave rise to criticism after a Super Bowl ad.

item.title: King Leatherbury, Trainer and Trader of Horses, Dies at 92
item.description: He trained mostly lesser-known, cheaper thoroughbreds in Maryland and was the fifth-winningest trainer in North American history.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir

media:content.media:description: King Leatherbury at Laurel Park racetrack in Maryland in 2003. He was inducted into the National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame in 2015.

item.title: In Munich, Europe Says It Is ‘De-risking’ From the U.S. Amid Trump’s Unpredictability
item.description: In Munich, European leaders were also talking about “de-risking” from the United States, citing President Trump’s unpredictability.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger

media:content.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio in Munich on Saturday.

item.title: Lucas Pinheiro Braathen of Brazil and Mikhail Shaidorov of Kazakhstan Win Olympic Gold Medals
item.description: A Brazilian skier secured South America’s maiden medal at a Winter Games the day after a Kazakh figure skater won his nation’s first gold in 32 years.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei and Tariq Panja

media:content.media:description: Mikhail Shaidorov of Kazakhstan won the gold medal in men’s figure skating on Friday at the Winter Olympics in Milan.

item.title: Woman Apparently Crushed by Trash Compactor in Building, Police Say
item.description: The medical examiner’s office is investigating the cause of death of Michelle Montgomery, 39, whose remains were found two weeks ago in a public housing building in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.
item.dc:creator: Maia Coleman

media:content.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Police Department had been investigating Michelle Montgomery’s death as possible foul play, but on Friday, the police said that investigators now believed her death was most likely an accident.

item.title: How ICE Is Pushing Tech Companies to Identify Protesters
item.description: The DHS is flooding social media companies with administrative subpoenas to identify accounts that are protesting ICE. Social media companies have pushed back but are largely complying. Our tech reporter, Sheera Frenkel, explains.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel, Christina Thornell, Valentina Caval, Thomas Vollkommer, Jon Hazell and June Kim

item.title: For Lunar New Year, Natasha Pickowicz and Sue Chan Throw a Hot Pot Potluck
item.description: To mark Lunar New Year and the publication of Natasha Pickowicz’s latest cookbook, guests brought the fixings, and she and Sue Chan supplied the broth.
item.dc:creator: Mackenzie Oster

item.title: Neighbor Recalls Investigators Searching Home Next Door in Guthrie Disappearance
item.description: David Curl, a retired lawyer, said the woman who lived there was distraught and did not know why investigators were focusing on her home.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy

media:content.media:description: F.B.I. and SWAT units raided a home in a neighborhood approximately two miles from Nancy Guthrie’s residence on Friday night.

item.title: ElRoy Face, Ace Forkballer and Effective Closer for Pirates, Dies at 97
item.description: Face was one of the first major-league hurlers to make the closer job a specialty. Not an overpowering pitcher, he finagled outs with a tricky forkball.
item.dc:creator: Richard Goldstein

media:content.media:description: ElRoy Face followed through after serving up a pitch against the Yankees at Yankee Stadium in the fifth game of the 1960 World Series. Face helped take the Pirates to a stunning defeat of the Yankees that year.

item.title: Pakistan Accused of Denying Treatment for Imran Khan’s Failing Eyesight
item.description: The lawyer for the former prime minister claimed he had lost 85 percent of the vision in his right eye because of delayed treatment in prison.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier

media:content.media:description: Former Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan in Lahore, Pakistan, in 2023.

item.title: Thousands Rally for Iran Regime Change in Cities Around the World
item.description: People protesting the Iranian government gathered near the security conference in Munich, as well as in other cities. More U.S.-Iran talks are expected Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Sanam Mahoozi, Jonathan Wolfe and Abdi Latif Dahir

media:content.media:description: Protesters held up flags of Iran from before the revolution at a Saturday demonstration organized on the sidelines of the Munich Security Conference.

item.title: At the Winter Olympics, Covering the Piste and Big Parma
item.description: What are a food reporter, the Miami bureau chief and a presidential photographer doing at the Games?
item.dc:creator: Kim Severson

media:content.media:description: The opening ceremony of the 2026 Milan Cortina Winter Olympics at San Siro Stadium last week.

item.title: The Sea Took Her Prosthetic Leg. Months Later, It Gave It Back.
item.description: Brenda Ogden lost her waterproof prosthetic leg 10 months ago, and with it, her zest for swimming. Then a local fossil hunter stumbled upon it.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai

item.title: The Depravity of Trump’s Immigrant Detention
item.description: The president’s immigration dragnet is vicious but not surprising.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie

media:content.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times

item.title: Mamdani Surprises Couples at City Hall and Officiates Their Weddings
item.description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani stopped by City Hall last Thursday, stepping in to officiate weddings and shocking couples as they arrived for their appointments.
item.dc:creator: Callie Holtermann

item.title: Classic Shrimp Scampi and More Valentine’s Day Recipes
item.description: It’s Feb. 14. Let’s do this.
item.dc:creator: Mia Leimkuhler

media:content.media:credit: David Malosh for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Simon Andrews.
media:content.media:description: Melissa Clark’s classic shrimp scampi.

item.title: Milo Rau’s ‘Hate Radio,’ ‘Pelicot Trial’ and More Theater of the Real
item.description: Milo Rau’s examination of the infamous broadcast that preceded the Rwandan genocide is onstage now. Two other works, including “The Pelicot Trial,” arrive in March.
item.dc:creator: Helen Shaw
item.category: Skirball Center for the Performing Arts

media:content.media:credit: Aliona Kardash for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: With his stage work, the Swiss director-activist Milo Rau examines episodes of historical violence in an attempt to give audiences some measure of insight.

item.title: New U.S. Boat Strike Kills 3 in the Caribbean
item.description: The attacks since early November had specifically targeted suspected drug smuggling boats in the Pacific Ocean.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )

media:content.media:description: This image from a video provided by the U.S. military shows what it says was a kinetic strike on a suspected drug trafficking vessel in the Caribbean Sea.

item.title: Los 5 lenguajes no oficiales del amor
item.description: En este Día de San Valentín expresa lo que sientes a tu manera.
item.dc:creator: Jancee Dunn

item.title: Chewy Cookies and Bowl Scrapers Forever
item.description: Sue Li takes the Bake Time questionnaire.
item.dc:creator: Sue Li and Vaughn Vreeland

media:content.media:credit: Johnny Miller for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Vivian Lui.
media:content.media:description: Genevieve Ko’s chewy brown butter cookies.

item.title: Roy Medvedev, Soviet Era Historian and Dissident, Is Dead at 100
item.description: His score of books and hundreds of essays documented Stalinist executions, Communist repressions and censorship, and the transition to post-Soviet Russia.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden

media:content.media:description: Roy Medvedev in Moscow in 1990. In the West, he was known as the most independent historian of the Soviet era.

item.title: The Magic Ring Hanging From the Sasha Calle Neck From Netflix’s “The Rip”
item.description: The actress from Netflix’s “The Rip” doesn’t allow anyone else to touch the ring, one of the rules that keep its magic alive.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Diamond

media:content.media:credit: Celeste Sloman for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: “I think I hold it with love and joy, and I’m grateful for it — not because of its magic qualities, but because it just holds a very tender memory,” said Sasha Calle.

item.title: Shivering Americans Snap Up Firewood as Winter Grinds On
item.description: Weeks of freezing temperatures and winter storms across parts of the United States have increased the demand for firewood and manufactured fire logs.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor

media:content.media:credit: Travis Dove for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Jason Loflin prepares firewood in Thomasville, N.C., on Friday. Bitter cold weather and a series of winter storms have intensified demand for logs for firewood.

item.title: What Would Carolyn Bessette Kennedy Have Thought of the New Calvin Klein?
item.description: As Ryan Murphy’s “Love Story” premieres, so does the Calvin Klein show. They don’t have the same style.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.category: Love Story: John F. Kennedy Jr. & Carolyn Bessette (TV Program)

item.title: Navalny Was Poisoned With Frog Toxin, European Governments Say
item.description: The toxin was found in the body of the Russian dissident Aleksei A. Navalny, who died in prison two years ago, five governments said, challenging Russia’s official account.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Nataliya Vasilyeva and Lynsey Chutel

media:content.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Aleksei A. Navalny in his office in Moscow in 2014. He was President Vladimir V. Putin’s most prominent political opponent when he died in a Russian prison in 2024.

item.title: Latest Updates: No Arrests After Searches Near Nancy Guthrie’s Home
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: Cassidy Araiza for The New York Times

item.title: David J. Farber, ‘Grandfather of the Internet,’ Dies at 91
item.description: A researcher, professor and federal policy adviser, he guided students who went on to do groundbreaking work in connecting the world online.
item.dc:creator: Peter Wayner

item.title: Software? No Way. We’re an A.I. Company Now!
item.description: As their stocks tank, software makers are rebranding themselves as A.I. innovators. Sparkle emojis are everywhere, but some efforts have been more successful than others.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Kessler

item.title: Welcome to the Voyage of the Damned
item.description: The tech heroes turned zeros are leading us to our doom.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd

media:content.media:credit: Photo Illustration by Philotheus Nisch for The New York Times

item.title: Can You Rely on A.I. to Translate Love?
item.description: A.I. translation has become a huge industry, but how accurate is it? Our tech reporter, Kashmir Hill, explores its successes and failures through a couple who relies on of A.I. translation to communicate.
item.dc:creator: Kashmir Hill, Gilad Thaler, Kassie Bracken, Jon Miller, Jon Hazell and Joey Sendaydiego

item.title: After Mass Shooting, the Town of Tumbler Ridge, British Columbia Is Forever Changed
item.description: The mass shooting in the remote British Columbia mining town has shocked and saddened the nation.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen

media:content.media:credit: Christinne Muschi/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Pierre Poilievre, the Conservative leader, Prime Minister Mark Carney and Governor General Mary Simon joined hands during a prayer by an Indigenous elder at the Tumbler Ridge vigil.

item.title: En busca de un hombre que no haga dramas
item.description: Había bajado tanto las expectativas de mis relaciones, que con que un hombre no gritara era suficiente.
item.dc:creator: Denise Mills

item.title: Pam Bondi’s ‘Cage Match’ and Trump’s Fraying Coalition
item.description: The round table reflects on a chaotic week of incompetence and meltdowns.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie, Michelle Cottle, David French and Derek Arthur
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; photograph by Roberto Schmidt/Getty

item.title: Live Updates: In Munich, Rubio Calls Europe a Friend but Says It Must Change
item.description: European leaders expressed relief at the tone of Secretary of State Marco Rubio’s remarks, but they made it clear that the trans-Atlantic rift remained.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
